annotation.TEXT: What makes this even worse is that this is the only place you can encounter Hammer Joes. If you somehow manage to kill them quick enough, you'll have a chance to get the best throwing chip in the entire game (the Hammer, which deals a whopping 160 damage and is multi-hitting).

Sword Man's Navi chip is pretty decent for the most part. It doesn't deal that much damage, but it does summon two large swords that home in on enemies. Once again, this follows the standard pattern of Navi chips in this game: Great for minor viruses, terrible for bosses.

Naturally though, most of the more easily accessible chips here are of the useless variety (Zap-Ring 3 and Satellite 2 being the most prominent). M-Cannon, Dyna-Wave, Hammer, and Big Bomb are the ones you'll want, but are way more annoying to get (especially in the case of Big Bomb, as they drop from an enemy you first meet while upside-down).

Skipping the re-fight with Gravity Man for now, let's quickly move on to the final area before the Zero Account. Incidentally, it also happens to be the home of my favorite Navi (design-wise, at least), along with my personal favorite song in the game.

By comparison to his stage, GravityMan.EXE is an absolute pushover. He's stationary for the entire fight, and only really has two distinct attacks (slow moving gravity bombs, and attempting to pull you in). You can only hurt him by hitting his head, but you can easily get by this with certain Navis and throwing chips. The only thing you'll really need to pay attention to is his arms, which can block out attacks if they're rotating in front of him.

Hey, you got your Gradius in my Mega Man! No really, this mini-boss is pretty much a Gradius enemy - right down to the fact that you need to hit its center to damage it. The circling yo-yo's can be destroyed, but it usually takes a while to get rid of them.

Time for the usual process. Like always, let's do a re-fight with the previous boss. Just to note however: This video contains two stages again, but any other re-fights will be held off until the start of the next video (the next two Navi chips aren't exactly worth getting right away).

For as much as I like this song, the stage itself is pretty "meh" at times. The inclusion of the Yort viruses so late in-game is kind of disappointing as well. The Yo-Yo chips have always been some of my favorite battle chips in the series, but in this game, you get access to them so late that they're barely worth using.
Like I said: ALL the stars. Believe it or not, this actually contributes to making his Navi chip incredibly disappointing. You'll see what I mean in the next video.

Word of advice when it comes to StarMan.EXE: Kill him quickly. If you mess around like I did towards the end of this fight when he has minimal HP left, you get to eat ALL the stars. Beyond that, this guy is a very counter-based fight. He'll teleport away if you try to shoot him or get too close, and he tends to immediately follow up with Star Arrows after you hit him.

Next to the Bank, the Abnormal Gravity section is probably my least favorite level in the entire game. It's not so much due to the gimmicks (which involve floor tiles that induce high gravity, along with the more classic gravity belts), but rather it's due to the enemy placement. There are actually a lot of strong enemies here that could be worth farming chips from, but their placement makes them way less ideal to grind off of when compared to the next few levels.
